text: Lady Robbins, Sir Alfred and John H. Cowles Sir Alfred Farthing Robbins (Launceston 1st August 1856 - 9th March 1931) was a British journalist, political biographer and freemason. He was initiated in 1888 in Gallery Lodge No. 1928, which catered for members of the Press Gallery of the House of Commons, and in 1901 became Master of that lodge. As President of the Board of General Purposes from 1913 until his death, he was described as "the Prime Minister of English Freemasonry". London correspondent of the Birmingham Daily Post since 1888, he was president of the Institute of Journalists in 1908, and has been chairman of its Orphan Fund since 1911. His portrait, painted by Philip Tennyson Cole, presented by the Institute of Journalists in 1931, is kept at Launceston Town Hall. He was a member of the National Liberal Club. He married Ellen Pitthttps://gw.geneanet.org/baronnet?lang=en&m;=S&n;=Robbins&p;= in 1882, and was the father of Clifton Robbins (1890-1964), the journalist, barrister, and writer of golden age detective fiction.1901 England, Wales & Scotland Census Transcription. Retrieved 26 August 2016. ==Works== * Five Years of Tory Rule: A Lesson and a Warning (1879) * Practical politics; or, The liberalism of to-day (1888) * Launceston, Past and Present (1888) * The early public life of William Ewart Gladstone: four times prime minister (1894) * English-Speaking Freemasonry (1930) * ==References== Category:1856 births Category:1931 deaths Category:Freemasons of the United Grand Lodge of England Category:English biographers Category:Knights Bachelor Category:People from Launceston, Cornwall
title: Alfred Farthing Robbins
